channel.title: Possible combinations
channel.description:
Say I have a list of 2 colours, Black and White. It's only possible to have 1 combination using these colours, because you can't have two of the same.
If I have 3 colours (Black, White and Red), there are 3 possible combination (Black+White, Black+Red, White+Red).
If I have 4 colours, there are 5 possible combinations and if I have 5 colours there are 10 possible combinations.
I'm trying to work out the relationship between the number of colours and the possible combinations. Here is some data:
[table] [tr][td]Colours[/td][td]Combinations[/td][/tr] [tr][td]0[/td][td]0[/td][/tr] [tr][td]1[/td][td]0[/td][/tr] [tr][td]2[/td][td]1[/td][/tr] [tr][td]3[/td][td]3[/td][/tr] [tr][td]4[/td][td]5[/td][/tr] [tr][td]5[/td][td]10[/td][/tr] [tr][td]6[/td][td]14[/td][/tr] [/table]

item.title: Possible combinations
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

Nah I’m just writing a decision engine (lolbing) and wanted to know a relationship so I could analyse performance without actually doing massive tests.

Read full topic

item.title: Possible combinations
item.dc:creator: @DarKcookie DarKcookie
item.description:
@DarKcookie wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:4, topic:345044”][quote author=DarKcookie link=topic=441420.msg3242543#msg3242543 date=1277052527]
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combination

n! / (2 * (n - 2)!)

Where n is the number of colours.

Your table value for 4 colors is wrong btw.
[/quote]
Isn’t that a very inefficient formula?
I think “(n * (n -1))/2” would work much better.[/quote]
I figured he needed it for some kind of homework assignment,
not high-performance calculations.
If calculation speed is an issue, your formula would ofcourse be the better choice.

Read full topic

item.title: Possible combinations
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:4, topic:345044”][quote author=DarKcookie link=topic=441420.msg3242543#msg3242543 date=1277052527]
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combination

n! / (2 * (n - 2)!)

Where n is the number of colours.

Your table value for 4 colors is wrong btw.
[/quote]
Isn’t that a very inefficient formula?
I think “(n * (n -1))/2” would work much better.[/quote]Yeah I’m using that, I’m not entirely sure why mr cookie posted that other one.

Read full topic

item.title: Possible combinations
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

Say I have a list of 2 colours, Black and White. It’s only possible to have 1 combination using these colours, because you can’t have two of the same.

If I have 3 colours (Black, White and Red), there are 3 possible combination (Black+White, Black+Red, White+Red).

If I have 4 colours, there are 5 possible combinations and if I have 5 colours there are 10 possible combinations.

I’m trying to work out the relationship between the number of colours and the possible combinations. Here is some data:

[table]
[tr][td]Colours[/td][td]Combinations[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]0[/td][td]0[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]1[/td][td]0[/td][/tr]
